title.rendered: How Many Watts of Solar Do I Need to Charge a 12 V 200Ah Battery?

content.rendered:
Understanding the terms of solar energy installation is vital to everyone willing to invest in green energy projects. Learn how to calculate how much your solar installation can cost, ranging from solar Panel to wattage of the Panel, the kind of battery used for charging systems, and the load/consumption in the system.

Before determining how many watts of solar energy I need to charge a 12v 200ah battery, it is important to understand how it gets charged. Various systems are used to charge solar batteries efficiently and effectively. These include solar panels, charge controllers, and batteries.

What is a Solar Panel?

A solar panel, also referred to as a photovoltaic (PV) panel, is equipment that transforms energy from the sun into electricity through the photovoltaic effect. A solar panel is built with numerous solar cells and semiconductor devices that generate direct current (DC) electricity when illuminated by sunlight. When the solar Panel is set up with other solar equipment, it generates electricity for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes.

What are the Known Brands of Solar Energy Panels?

  1. SunPower: Known for high-efficiency solar panels and a long-standing reputation for quality and durability.
  2. LG: Produces efficient and high-quality solar panels with a strong emphasis on aesthetics and performance.
  3. Panasonic: Offers high-efficiency solar panels and is recognised for quality manufacturing and product reliability.
  4. Canadian Solar: Provides a wide range of solar panels with a good balance of quality and affordability.
  5. JinkoSolar: Known for its cost-effective solar panels and is one of the world’s largest solar module manufacturers.
  6. Trina Solar: Produces high-quality solar panels focusing on innovation and reliability.
  7. REC Group: Offers high-quality panels known for their longevity and robust design.
  8. Hanwha Q Cells: Known for their efficient and reliable solar panels.

What is the Purpose of using Solar Energy?

  • Solar energy is renewable and clean, diminishing reliance on fossil fuels and lessening environmental harm.
  • Solar power systems are sustainable and cost-effective over time, offering decentralized energy solutions.
  • Embracing solar energy supports global initiatives against climate change and promotes sustainability for future generations.

How Many Watts of Solar Do I Need to Charge a 12V 200 Ah Battery?

To calculate the number of watts of solar panels needed to charge a 12V 200Ah battery, you can use the following formula:

Watts = Volts x Amps x Hours

In this case:
Watts = 12V x 200Ah
Watts = 2400W

In other words,

The total energy stored in the battery is VxAh, so in this case 12×200 = 2400VAh

What does this mean? Let’s say the battery has 95% charging efficiency, and the total energy required to charge the battery is 2400/0.95 = 2526 J . Now, this much energy needs to be supplied by solar panels during the daytime. Also, here, we have to take the efficiency of solar panels somewhere 85% due to dust, temperature, wiring, etc.

So, we use the following formula.

PVP x EquDaylightHours x Efficiency = Battery Voltage x Ah / Charging Efficiency

PVP = 2526 / (5.5 x 0.85)

PVP = 540 W (Ideal Case)

Generally, we never discharge the battery fully as it severely reduces its lifetime. Typically, the Flat panel Battery’s allowable DoD (Depth of discharge) is 50%, and the Tubular is 60%. So, keeping this in mind, the Power requirement of the Panel also decreases.

So, I will suggest the following configuration

300 – 370W , 24V Poly-crystalline Solar panel

20A MPPT charge controller

Charging time is about 6 hrs

Never connect the battery directly to the solar Panel; the Solar Panel should be connected to the battery either through a solar inverter or a solar charge controller.

How Do I Convert from WATTS to AMPS

It is simple to calculate how many watts are needed in an Amp system. To convert from watts to Amp, divide whatever amount of watts by the volts.

Amps = Watts / Volts

In other words, by converting from amps to watts, multiply the resulting amps by volts.

ie.

Watts = Amps x Volts

What Size of Solar Panel Do I Need To Charge a 100AH Battery?

To calculate this, first consider the battery. i.e. 100AH which is 12volts. convert to watts by multiplying the volts.

i.e., 100AH Lithium Battery x 12V = 1200 Watts

Next, let’s say we have 8 hours to charge the battery; how many watts of solar panels do we need to charge the battery?

1200watts/ 8H = 150W of solar panels.

In the same vein, we can get another wattage by simply multiplying it with its corresponding watts and volts to get the answer.

PWM or MPPT: What Charges a 12V 200Ah battery faster? Are solar panels in parallel or in series?

There are two main types of charge controllers: PWM (sometimes called switch mode) and MPPT.

PWM controllers work by monitoring battery voltage and act as electronic switches to connect solar panels to the battery. Once the voltage reaches a preset level, typically around 14.4 volts for a 12-volt battery, they disconnect the panels, repeating this cycle rapidly. However, they “waste” any voltage exceeding the preset level, limiting their output to the panel’s amp rating. In contrast, MPPT controllers are more sophisticated and expensive, analyzing the total wattage available from the panel and utilizing all available power efficiently by adjusting volts and amps. This allows them to deliver higher charge rates than PWM controllers. When using multiple panels with a PWM controller, parallel connections are recommended to maximize amps and minimize wasted voltage. On the other hand, MPPT controllers can handle higher input voltages, making series connections preferable for longer charging periods, especially in cloudy conditions.

For example, an off-grid system with 5.7 kW of solar panels can demonstrate the difference. Utilizing a PWM controller limits the system’s output to 57 volts at 63 amps, resulting in only 3.6 kW of power. However, with an MPPT controller, the system could deliver approximately 100 amps at 57 volts, significantly increasing charging capacity. Despite the potential benefits of MPPT controllers, some system owners may overlook their advantages and opt for cheaper alternatives initially. Retrofitting with an MPPT controller later can improve system performance and reduce reliance on backup generators, as demonstrated in the case described. However, uninformed installations can lead to suboptimal system performance and premature ageing of components, underscoring the importance of thorough understanding and careful planning when setting up solar systems.
